description: Borrowed from Turkish kilim, from Persian گلیم‎ (gelim), akin to Aramaic גלימא‎ (galīmā, “blanket, garment, cloth”), both from Ancient Greek κάλυμμα (kálumma, “cover, top, covering”) derived from καλύπτω (kalúptō, “to cover”), from Proto-Indo-European *ḱel- (“to cover”).

entries.meaning: A flat tapestry-woven carpet or rug from Turkey or Kurdistan.
examples: The khan they all deferred to was a wiry, hook-nosed man with a growth of grey stubble on his chin, who sat on a kelim, listening to the others' arguments without moving a muscle.
